bibl.title: Letter from James E. Peabody to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 5, 1943

div1.p: Peabody requests Kean's assistance in editing the copy of his account of the campaign to get the Yellow Fever Bill passed into law. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from James E. Peabody to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 5, 1943
div1.opener:
P.S - Can you give me Mrs. Wood's address?- also Mrs. Gorgas?
Aus July 28/1943
HILL TOP COTTAGE
Acworth
New Hampshire
July 5, 1943.
Dear General Kean:
div1.p:
It is a long time since I heard from you directly. Several recent
letters from Dr. Henceh told me of his meetings with you and of Mrs. Reed's
birthday party. I do hope this letter finds you in good health and in the
complete enjoyment of your well-earned retirement.

You weill see by the above heading that we have left Newtonville
and have made our home in New Hampshire. If you glance through the enclosed
letter I wrote to my Boy Printers you will see how completely happy we are
up here.

Under another cover Enclosed I am venturing to send you a rather complete
account of the three-year campaign we waged before the Yellow Fever Bill
became law--a campaign in which your generous assistance was invaluable.
I have written this up because of the number of people who have sent to me
for information. Several letters with detailed questions have come from
Dr. Hench, Mrs. Laura Woods and Sidney Howard. Thinking there might be
others I have put down on these pages the various steps as I remember them.
Before sending out any of these copies I am hoping you will be able to look
over the pages and make the needed changes. If this is asking too much do
not hesitate to refuse me.

Will you also tell me frankly whether you think General Ireland,
Mrs. Reed, Mrs. L Wood, and perhaps others would care to get a revised copy.
I certainly do not wish to bore my friends. Can you tell me what you think
of Mrs. Woods life of Major Reed (which I have read with interest) of “Yellow
Jack” and of the play of Sidney Howard's? Have you any recent news of Kis-
singer? We have written the Kissingers but have not heard lately.
With all good wishes to my good friend to whom we owe so much
